message.content:
I wanna setup a group in which 2 agents will talk to each other and I can interact too. How is the way to do this?
  Start reading the docs to figure out on /docs
 
  Instruct me how to do it as an user

content.message: I wanna setup a group in which 2 agents will talk to each other and I can interact too. How is the way to do this? Start reading the docs to figure out on /docs Instruct me how to do it as an user

Based on the docs, here's how to set up a **2-agent group where they talk to each other and you can interact too**: ## Setup ### 1. Define 2 agents in your config ```json5 { agents: { list: [ { id: "agent-a", workspace: "~/.openclaw/workspace-a" }, { id: "agent-b", workspace: "~/.openclaw/workspace-b" }, ], }, } ``` ### 2. Enable agent-to-agent communication Off by default. Must explicitly enable: ```json5 { tools: { agentToAgent: { enabled: true, allow: ["agent-a", "agent-b"], }, }, } ``` This lets agents use `sessions_send` to message each other. ### 3. Route both agents to the same group (broadcast) So both agents see and respond to your messages in the same chat: ```json5 { broadcast: { strategy: "parallel", // both respond simultaneously "120363403215116621@g.us": ["agent-a", "agent-b"], // or for a DM: "+15551234567": ["agent-a", "agent-b"], }, } ``` ### 4. Agent-to-agent messaging via `sessions_send` Once enabled, either agent can message the other: ```javascript { "tool": "sessions_send", "params": { "sessionKey": "agent:agent-b:main", "message": "What do you think about X?", "timeoutSeconds": 30 // waits for reply (ping-pong) } } ``` - Supports up to 5 ping-pong turns (configurable via `session.agentToAgent.maxPingPongTurns`) - Agent replies `REPLY_SKIP` to stop the conversation ## How it works in practice - **You send a message** in the group → both agents see it and respond (broadcast) - **Agent A can ask Agent B** something via `sessions_send` → gets a reply back - **You see everything** — agent-to-agent messages get announced back to the requester chat - Each agent has **isolated sessions, workspace, and tools** ## Unresolved questions - Which channel are you using? (WhatsApp, Discord, Slack?) — affects the group ID format - Do you want parallel (both respond at once) or sequential (one after the other)? - Do agents need different tool access / personalities, or same config? - Do you want agents to proactively talk to each other, or only when you trigger it?

message.content: Im running openclaw now and already have 2 agents , discord and telegram configured. Tell me the prompt i need to say in order for it to configure it how to do it

content.message: Im running openclaw now and already have 2 agents , discord and telegram configured. Tell me the prompt i need to say in order for it to configure it how to do it

content.text: I need to understand how openclaw config is actually applied — whether it's a config file you edit or a command you give the running instance.

content.message: I need to understand how openclaw config is actually applied — whether it's a config file you edit or a command you give the running instance.

content.text:
You have 3 options. Easiest first:

## Option 1: Edit config directly (hot-reloads automatically)

Open `~/.openclaw/openclaw.json` and add:

```json5
{
  // ... your existing config ...

  // enable agent-to-agent messaging
  tools: {
    agentToAgent: {
      enabled: true,
      allow: ["AGENT_A_ID", "AGENT_B_ID"],  // replace with your agent IDs
    },
  },

  // both agents respond in same group
  broadcast: {
    strategy: "parallel",
    "YOUR_GROUP_ID": ["AGENT_A_ID", "AGENT_B_ID"],
  },
}
```

Save — openclaw hot-reloads automatically.

## Option 2: CLI commands

```bash
openclaw config set tools.agentToAgent.enabled true
openclaw config set tools.agentToAgent.allow '["agent-a", "agent-b"]'
openclaw config set broadcast.strategy "parallel"
openclaw config set broadcast.YOUR_GROUP_ID '["agent-a", "agent-b"]'
```

## Option 3: Control UI

Open `http://127.0.0.1:18789` → **Config** tab → edit visually.

---

## What you need to fill in

I don't know your exact setup, so replace:
- `AGENT_A_ID` / `AGENT_B_ID` → your actual agent IDs (check `agents.list` in your config)
- `YOUR_GROUP_ID` → your Discord channel ID (format: `discord:channel:123456`) or Telegram group ID

To find your agent IDs:
```bash
openclaw config get agents.list
```

Which group/channel do you want them both talking in — Discord or Telegram?

content.message: You have 3 options. Easiest first: ## Option 1: Edit config directly (hot-reloads automatically) Open `~/.openclaw/openclaw.json` and add: ```json5 { // ... your existing config ... // enable agent-to-agent messaging tools: { agentToAgent: { enabled: true, allow: ["AGENT_A_ID", "AGENT_B_ID"], // replace with your agent IDs }, }, // both agents respond in same group broadcast: { strategy: "parallel", "YOUR_GROUP_ID": ["AGENT_A_ID", "AGENT_B_ID"], }, } ``` Save — openclaw hot-reloads automatically. ## Option 2: CLI commands ```bash openclaw config set tools.agentToAgent.enabled true openclaw config set tools.agentToAgent.allow '["agent-a", "agent-b"]' openclaw config set broadcast.strategy "parallel" openclaw config set broadcast.YOUR_GROUP_ID '["agent-a", "agent-b"]' ``` ## Option 3: Control UI Open `http://127.0.0.1:18789` → **Config** tab → edit visually. --- ## What you need to fill in I don't know your exact setup, so replace: - `AGENT_A_ID` / `AGENT_B_ID` → your actual agent IDs (check `agents.list` in your config) - `YOUR_GROUP_ID` → your Discord channel ID (format: `discord:channel:123456`) or Telegram group ID To find your agent IDs: ```bash openclaw config get agents.list ``` Which group/channel do you want them both talking in — Discord or Telegram?
